title: Shreyas Waghe
text:
Bio
Iâ€™m a third-year student at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, studying Computer Science and Applied Mathematics. I study and research mathematics â€“ Fair Machine Learning, Statistical Physics, and Dynamical Systems.
My interests are at the intersection of Computational and Applied Mathematics, and the development and application of mathematical theory to support mathematical computing.
Iâ€™ve had graduate coursework in Linear Algebra & Calculus, ODE Systems, Machine Learning, Probabilistic Graphical Models, and Computational Biology. I describe more of my coursework here.
Iâ€™ve been an Undergraduate Researcher at:

Fair and Explainable Decision-Making Lab, UMass CS
PALM Research Lab, Brown University CS (with an NSF Undergraduate Fellowship!)
Machta Research Group, UMass Physics

Additionally, Iâ€™ve TA-ed the following courses at UMass:

Pre-Calculus (Math 100, 101)
Computational Physics (Physics 281)
Artificial Intelligence (CS 383)
Introduction to the Theory of Computation (CS 250)



Reaching out
Iâ€™m active on LinkedIn, and Iâ€™m always available on e-mail.

title: Courses
text:
Any course numbered 500 or higher is considered a dual undergraduate-graduate course.
Any course numbered 600 or higher is considered a graduate course for students on the doctoral track, and undergraduate students need special instructor permission to enroll.
Academic mentors named alongside their courses.

title: About Me
text:
What I do
My interests in Mathematics are broad, and I would say much of what I do aspires to:

Describe physical phenomena quantitatively and robustly
Drive Computer Science practice with a strong justification in Mathematical theory

In concrete terms, Iâ€™m mostly engaged in:

Scientific Computing - with C++, Python and Julia
Machine Learning and Data Science
Dynamical Systems

You might know me from:

UMass â€“ Iâ€™m involved in Undergraduate Research and Teaching.

My research is in Theoretical Machine Learning, Statistical Physics and broadly Applied Math in general.
Iâ€™ve been a TA for Pre-Calculus courses, Computational Physics (Phy 281), Artificial Intelligence (CS 383).
Since Fall 2023, Iâ€™m a Residential Peer Mentor in Wheeler Hall.
